Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: High-Performance Metal Pretreatments
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project aims to develop a chromate- and phosphate-free metal surface pre-treatment product that reduces cost, and provides significant environmental and health benefits. Iron and zinc phosphate chemicals are currently widely used in surface treatment processes, which require from 7 to 10 process steps, consume energy to heat treatment baths, and produce a large quantity of waste that must be treated. This adds cost, and results in phosphate discharge to the environment. Based on the Phase I project, a chromate- and phosphate-free pre-treatment chemical will be further developed in this project. This chemical reduces the number of pre-treatment process to less than 5 steps, can be used at ambient temperature, and produces 90% less waste. It is expected to demonstrate enhanced performance in corrosion protection and paint adhesion over similar products.

The broader commercial impacts of this project will be to dramatically reduce cost, complexity and negative environmental impact of metal surface pretreatment in manufacturing processes without compromising performance. Potential applications will be in automobile, aerospace, steel (coil coatings), consumer electronics, appliance, and many other industries. An important societal impact will be the better protection to workers in plants, as this process is not toxic and does not require elaborate waste disposal procedures. This project will also enhance the scientific understanding of mechanisms by which pretreatments contribute to the protection of metals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project was to improve the efficiency and reduce the environmental impact of manufacturing through the use of an innovative metal pretreatment technology. The fundamental chemistry of this novel pretreatment technology is based on advanced silicon compounds combined with transition metal compounds. The major benefit of this technology is the elimination of toxic heavy metal ions and/or environmentally-unfriendly phosphates contained in traditional pretreatments. The pretreatment products derived from this novel technology can be easily applied onto a wide range of metals/alloys by immersion or spraying prior to priming or topcoating. The metals suitable for these pretreatment products include mild steel, stainless steel, aluminum alloys and galvanized steel. This pretreatment solution quickly modifies a metal surface with a nano-structured pretreatment film which consequently provides excellent paint adhesion for a variety of paints and coatings.

The broader commercial impacts of this project are the following: (1) Increase life of engineering metals/alloys by maximizing protectiveness of a variety of advanced organic coatings; (2) use non-toxic, environmentally-friendly chemistry to reduce the health and environment impacts and disposal costs of hazardous chemicals used in traditional metal pretreatment products such as phosphate-based and hexavalent chromium-based pretreatments; (3) simplify the metal treatment process to reduce consumption and disposal of water, (4) enable ambient operation to reduce energy consumption such as bath heating; and (5) provide “drop-in” technology to lower capital cost.  

The penetrated markets for these pretreatments throughout Phase II include general industry, home appliance and consumer electronics. Field testing is currently underway in heavy equipment and machinery, automotive and sheet steel milling industries.
